p: In vitro and in vivo, α-syn can undergo amyloid fibril formation, with a typical cross-β sheet structure by a nucleation-dependent mechanism [ 97, 111]. The nucleation process is the rate-limiting step in fibril formation that gives rise to the production of soluble oligomers, proto-fibrils and finally mature amyloid fibrils ( Figure 2c). Recently, several lines of evidence indicate that the soluble oligomers, rather than the mature fibrils, may be the toxic species associated with PD [ 112], and LB/LN are a protective and inert forms in which fibrils converge [ 113].
